intro: Sida guilleminiana, commonly known as the Mexican mallow, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its hairy, quadrangular stems and heart-shaped leaves with serrated edges. Its flowers are typically pink or purple, with five petals and a prominent central stamen. Sida guilleminiana is often found in disturbed soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade.
